extracted_ttps.description: The malware employs a multi-step process and utilizes system commands like arp, at, ipconfig, net, and netsh, indicating potential malicious behavior through command and scripting interpreter execution.
The malware created a scheduled task to maintain persistence on the compromised system by automatically loading a malicious DLL file at each system boot.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The malware exfiltrated data over a command and control channel, using distinctive strings and prefixes to verify and maintain its activities.
The generation of a 24-byte value for validating the legitimacy of the client's connection could imply a brute force mechanism to guess or crack the value.
The malware was executed by the user through a legitimate security software designed to encrypt web communications using digital certificates.
The malware modified registry entries to execute legitimate files for malicious purposes, ensuring a resilient persistence mechanism.
The malware used obfuscated files and information, such as encrypted configuration data and base64-encoded strings, to evade detection.
The malware gathers various information about the victim's computer, such as computer name and OS details
The adversary exploited vulnerabilities in legitimate software to gain initial access to the system.
The actor's initial compromise of the victim involved exploiting vulnerabilities within the software exploit
The malware uses a mechanism to validate the response data received from the C2 server
The actor used a DLL side-loading technique to deploy the SIGNBT malware
The malware disables user-mode syscall hooking and restores system library memory sections
The malware uses a mechanism to communicate with the C2 server

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The malware exfiltrates data to the C2 server
The actor used credential dumping utilities to collect victim credentials

rules.title: Suspicious Archiving and Immediate Upload to Paste Services
rules.description: Detects use of archiving tools (PowerShell Compress-Archive, 7z, tar) that include references to public paste services (pastebin.com, webhook.site) when launched from typical document‑handling parent processes, indicating possible Archive Collected Data activity.

detection.condition: (archive_ps or archive_ps_webhook or archive_7z or archive_7z_webhook or archive_tar or archive_tar_webhook) and parent_suspicious

falsepositives: Legitimate use of PowerShell Compress-Archive by administrators.
System administrators using 7z or tar for backup purposes.
Users uploading compressed files to internal paste services for collaboration.

rules.title: Suspicious Registry Run Key Creation via Office or Browser Initiated reg.exe with Paste Service URLs
rules.description: Detects execution of reg.exe that adds entries to the HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run key when launched from Office applications or browsers and includes references to known paste-like services, indicating a likely persistence setup after a phishing download.

detection.condition: reg_add_run and (parent_outlook or parent_winword or parent_excel or parent_browser or parent_browser2) and (cmd_pastebin or cmd_webhook)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that add startup entries via reg.exe
Software installers that configure Run keys during deployment
IT automation tools that modify user startup settings

rules.title: Suspicious Office Application Launch of Command Shells with Potential Phishing Payloads
rules.description: Detects Office applications (Outlook, Word, Excel) spawning command-line or scripting processes with command lines that contain download utilities, encoded PowerShell flags, or references to public paste services, indicative of phishing‑delivered malicious payload execution.

detection.condition: (selection_parent or selection_parent2 or selection_parent3) and (selection_child or selection_child2 or selection_child3 or selection_child4) and (selection_suspicious or selection_suspicious2 or selection_suspicious3 or selection_suspicious4 or selection_suspicious5 or selection_suspicious6 or selection_suspicious7 or selection_suspicious8)

falsepositives: Legitimate IT automation scripts launched from Office macros
User‑initiated PowerShell or cmd sessions opened from Office applications for troubleshooting
Scheduled tasks or group policies that run scripts via Office processes
Security tools that use Office as a launch point for benign utilities

attacks.description: Add a new user to the system using the net.exe command

attacks.expected_behavior: The IP address of the system will be released

attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and runs at system start, writing a test file to the temp directory

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Encode a test string using certutil, simulating data exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes the contents of the test.txt file and writes it to output.txt, demonstrating data exfiltration over a command and control channel

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Encode a test string using PowerShell, simulating command and control channel transmission
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes the test string using Base64 and prints the result, demonstrating the use of a command and control channel

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Establish a connection using net.exe, simulating command and control channel establishment
attacks.expected_behavior: The command establishes a connection on port 8080, simulating the establishment of a command and control channel

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration using curl to send test data to a hypothetical command and control server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a POST request with test data to the specified URL, simulating data exfiltration.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration using netcat to send sensitive data to a command and control server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses netcat to send the string 'sensitive_data' to the specified server and port, simulating exfiltration of sensitive information.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration and execution of a malicious script downloaded from a command and control server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a script from the specified URL and executes it using bash, simulating the exfiltration of data and potential execution of malicious code. Note: This command has a high safety risk due to the execution of potentially malicious scripts.

attacks.command: for /l %x in (1,1,100) do net user test %x /add
attacks.description: Basic brute force attempt to guess a password by trying numbers 1 through 100
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to add a new user with a password that increments from 1 to 100, demonstrating a basic brute force mechanism.

attacks.description: Intermediate brute force attempt using PowerShell to guess a password by trying numbers 1 through 100
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will use PowerShell to attempt to add a new user with a password that increments from 1 to 100, demonstrating an intermediate brute force mechanism.

attacks.description: Advanced brute force attempt to guess a password by trying filenames in the TEMP directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to add new users with passwords that are filenames in the TEMP directory, demonstrating an advanced brute force mechanism.

attacks.command: for i in {1..100}; do echo "Attempt $i: Trying password123"; done
attacks.description: Basic brute force simulation using a bash loop
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output attempts to guess a password, simulating a brute force attack without actually interacting with any system or service.

attacks.description: Intermediate brute force attack using hydra
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to brute force an SSH connection using a wordlist, simulating a more targeted attack. Note: Requires hydra to be installed.

attacks.command: while IFS= read -r line; do echo "Attempting password: $line"; done < wordlist.txt
attacks.description: Advanced dictionary attack simulation
attacks.expected_behavior: The command reads a wordlist file line by line, simulating a dictionary attack by attempting each line as a potential password.

attacks.description: This command uses certutil to download a malicious executable from a URL and execute it. This demonstrates the User Execution technique by simulating a user downloading and executing a malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will be downloaded and executed, potentially causing harm to the system.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to start a new process that executes notepad.exe with an argument that displays a message box. This demonstrates the User Execution technique by simulating a user executing a command that runs a legitimate program with malicious arguments.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box will be displayed with the text 'Hello World!'.

attacks.description: This command uses cmd.exe to create a new file in the temp directory and then execute it using the start command. This demonstrates the User Execution technique by simulating a user creating and executing a malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file will be created in the temp directory and executed, displaying the text 'Hello World!'.

attacks.description: Basic example of executing a script from a temporary directory, simulating user execution of a potentially malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes the script, potentially leading to malicious activity if the script were actually malicious.

attacks.description: Intermediate example where a user executes a downloaded script, assuming it's legitimate, demonstrating how malware can be executed through user interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script executes, potentially installing or running malicious software if it were not a test scenario.

attacks.description: Advanced example where a user, thinking they are executing a legitimate script, unknowingly executes a malicious command with elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script executes with elevated privileges, potentially leading to significant system compromise if the script were malicious.

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to execute notepad.exe on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad.exe will be executed on startup

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v Test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Hello World! > $env:TEMP\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Add a new registry key to execute a command on startup and write to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World!'

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to execute notepad.exe on startup using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad.exe will be executed on startup

attacks.description: Appends a malicious command to the rc.local file to execute on boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed on the next system boot.

attacks.description: Modifies the crontab to run a malicious command at regular intervals.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed at the specified interval.

attacks.description: Creates a new profile script in /etc/profile.d/ to execute a malicious command on user login.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed when a user logs in.

attacks.expected_behavior: A file named encoded.txt will be created in the Public directory, containing the base64 encoded content of test.txt

attacks.description: Decode a base64 encoded file using PowerShell to demonstrate retrieval of obfuscated information
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named decoded.txt will be created in the Public directory, containing the decoded content of encoded.txt

attacks.description: Create a file, encode it, and save the encoded version to a new file using cmd and certutil, demonstrating a basic obfuscation technique
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files will be created in the TEMP directory: obfuscated.txt containing 'Hello World', and obfuscated_encoded.txt containing its base64 encoded version

attacks.description: Decodes a base64-encoded string and executes it as a bash command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print 'Hello world!' to the console, demonstrating the decoding and execution of obfuscated data

attacks.description: Decrypts a file using AES-256-CBC decryption
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a decrypted file /tmp/decrypted.txt from the encrypted file /tmp/encrypted.txt

attacks.description: Modify the system startup to include the SSH daemon, demonstrating modification of a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH daemon will be configured to start automatically on system boot.

attacks.description: Enable and start the SSH daemon using systemctl, demonstrating an advanced method of creating/modifying a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH daemon will be enabled to start at boot and started immediately, allowing for secure remote connections.

attacks.description: Start the Telnet service to demonstrate application layer protocol usage
attacks.expected_behavior: Telnet service starts, allowing for remote access

attacks.description: Download a file using certutil to demonstrate application layer protocol for data transfer
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt is downloaded from the specified URL to the temp directory

attacks.description: Establish a TCP connection to a remote server using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A TCP connection is briefly established to the specified server and then closed

attacks.description: Listen on port 8080 for incoming connections, simulating a C&C server waiting for commands.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command listens on the specified port, allowing for incoming connections. It does not initiate any malicious activities by itself.

attacks.description: Connect to a hypothetical C&C server at example.com on port 8080, simulating a client reaching out to a command and control server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to establish a connection to the specified host and port. Replace example.com with a test server address to avoid unintended connections.

attacks.description: Combine echoing a test string with listening on a port, demonstrating how data could be sent over a network protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command listens on port 8081 and sends the string 'Hello, World!' to any client that connects, simulating data exchange over a network protocol.

attacks.description: Lists all running processes using WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes

attacks.description: Creates a new process using WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches the calculator application

attacks.description: Queries the operating system information using WMI through PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays operating system information

attacks.description: This command attempts to use PowerShell to execute a WMI query on a Linux system, assuming PowerShell is installed. It's a basic demonstration and may not work as expected due to platform differences.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command may fail or produce an error due to the incompatibility of WMI with Linux, but it demonstrates an attempt to use WMI-like functionality.

attacks.description: This command uses 'wmic' to query WMI information from a remote Windows host. It requires the 'wmic' command to be available on the Linux system, which might be possible through certain packages or installations.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to retrieve operating system information from a remote Windows host using WMI, demonstrating WMI usage in a Linux context for remote Windows management.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to create a ManagementObjectSearcher for WMI queries, specifically targeting the Win32_OperatingSystem class. It's an advanced demonstration that requires PowerShell to be installed and configured on the Linux system.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command demonstrates advanced WMI querying using PowerShell on a Linux system, though its success depends on the availability and configuration of PowerShell.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to compress all files in the Public Documents folder into an archive named 'archive.zip' located in the user's temp directory, overwriting any existing file with the same name.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of public documents in the temp directory.

attacks.description: This advanced command utilizes the System.IO.Compression.FileSystem assembly in PowerShell to create a zip archive from the Public Documents folder, demonstrating an alternative method of archiving data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of public documents using an alternative method.

attacks.description: This basic command uses the makecab utility to create a cabinet archive of files in the Public Documents folder, stored in the temp directory, showcasing a legacy method of archiving.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a cabinet archive of public documents.

attacks.description: Archives system logs and password file using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tarball named 'collected_data.tar.gz' containing system logs and the password file in the current directory

attacks.description: Archives hosts file and system logs using zip
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive named 'collected_data.zip' containing the hosts file and system logs in the current directory

attacks.description: Archives kernel logs using gzip
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a gzip archive named 'collected_kernel_logs.gz' containing kernel logs in the current directory

attacks.description: Add a test value to the Run key using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The command adds a new value named 'test' to the Run key, which will execute notepad.exe on startup.

attacks.description: Modify an existing value in the Run key using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command modifies the existing 'test' value in the Run key to execute notepad.exe on startup.

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce /v test /t REG_SZ /d "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe /c echo Hello World!" /f
attacks.description: Add a test value to the RunOnce key using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The command adds a new value named 'test' to the RunOnce key, which will execute a command that prints 'Hello World!' on startup and then deletes itself.

attacks.description: Creates a simple autostart file in the user's home directory to simulate persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.desktop will be created in the .config/autostart directory, which could potentially be used to execute commands at startup.

attacks.command: crontab -l | { cat; echo '* * * * * echo test_string > /tmp/test_cron'; } | crontab -
attacks.description: Modifies the user's crontab to include a new job that runs every minute, simulating a persistence technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: The crontab will be modified to include a new job that writes 'test_string' to /tmp/test_cron every minute.

attacks.description: Enables a systemd service named test.service for the current user, simulating another form of persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The test.service will be enabled to start at user login, demonstrating a method of achieving persistence on Linux systems.

attacks.description: Basic phishing attempt using PowerShell to display a message and open a benign website.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a message and opens a website in the default browser.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c start https://example.com && echo Phishing attempt detected > %TEMP%\phish.txt
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing attempt using cmd.exe to open a website and create a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a website and creates a file in the temp directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Alert'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300,200); $form.ShowDialog();}"
attacks.description: Advanced phishing attempt using PowerShell to create a popup form.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a popup form with a title.

attacks.command: echo 'Phishing attempt: Click this link http://example.com' > phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Basic phishing email simulation using echo command
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file named phishing_email.txt with a phishing message

attacks.description: Intermediate phishing simulation using curl and xdg-open
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads an HTML page from a specified URL and opens it with the default browser

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo "Phishing alert: Your password has been compromised" | mail -s "Password Alert" user@example.com'
attacks.description: Advanced phishing simulation using bash and mail command
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a phishing email to a specified user with a password compromise alert
